The Ministry of Labour and Employment has rejected the 21-day ultimatum given to the Federal Government by the Nigeria Medical Association saying it is in direct collision with the Memorandum of Understanding signed on August 21.
Read Also: NMA Issues FG 21-Day Ultimatum To Resolve Industrial Disputes With NARD, OthersThis ultimatum was part of the resolutions reached during its National Executive Council (NEC) meeting, held in Benin City last week.
NMA’s ultimatum is the latest in the lingering tussle between the Nigerian government and NARD which has gone on strike since July 31.
But the NMA has thrown its weight behind the striking doctors and other health workers.
“The Nigerian Medical Association fully supports all her affiliates in their efforts to improve the healthcare delivery in Nigeria and the welfare of her members,” it assured.

headline: We Fired At Illegal Bunkers, Not Cargo Boat – DHQ
summarized_story:
According to the Defence Headquarters (DHQ) the report that civilians were shot at without cause is false.
“The helicopter encountered an illegal oil bunkerers’ boat popularly called ‘Cotonou Boat’.
The crew fired back at the helicopter and the boat was engaged accordingly.
“The 2 speedboats detached from the convoy at high speed leaving the ‘Cotonou Boat’ which was neutralized,” General Sawyerr narrated.
“The suspects are still at large and a manhunt has been sent out to apprehend them,” the DHQ Spokesman added.

headline: Nigeria: Governor Lalong Says People Using Politics and Religion to Perpetuate Crisis in Plateau
summarized_story:
Plateau State Governor Simon Lalong has said there’s a clear desire by people to use politics, religion and ethnicity to achieve their objective of ensuring the state is in perpetual crisis.
We must not allow them to use politics, religion, and ethnicity to divert our attention from their criminal activities.
Beginning from Monday 30th August 2021, the curfew shall be enforced from 6 pm to 6 am until further notice,” he said.

headline: Nigeria: Again, Katsina Governor Masari Canvasses for State Police
summarized_story:
For the umpteenth time, the Katsina State Governor, Aminu Bello Masari, has said if the country truly intended to get a hold of the deteriorating security situation, then, it must embrace multi-level policing otherwise called state police.
The president’s home state governor disclosed that this week, his government would complete the training of 500 vigilantes, who were trained by the police and armed forces, saying in the coming week, training for another 500 would be completed.
Lamenting that Katsina, which has an estimated population of between seven and eight million persons, the governor claimed presently has only 3,000 policemen.
Katsina State as of 2006 had a population of 5.6 million, even if we are growing at three per cent, what would be the population by 2021?
Speaking further, Masari explained that, in his state, a local government with 34 policemen, had over 300 villages and towns to secure.

Meanwhile, justice Iheka of the Imo State High Court again ordered INEC to publish Umeoji’s name.
What the commission does in terms of obedience to court orders is that if a judgment comes today, the commission obeys the order, because it is the latest in time.

headline: Nigeria: Governing APC States Align With FG on 15% Annual Release to Healthcare Services
summarized_story:
They have also resolved to undertake the establishment of sustainable healthcare financing systems such as health insurance and health emergency trust fund.
The meeting was held on Thursday, August 26, 2021, at Ilorin, Kwara State, with the theme “Improving Primary Health Care Delivery in APC State”.
The objectives of the meeting included Identifying challenges of primary healthcare delivery; Proffering sustainable solutions aimed at tackling the identified challenges confronting primary healthcare delivery; Facilitating the adoption of uniform implementation of policy initiatives on primary healthcare delivery across all APC states, among others.
It further resolved that priority consideration should be given to maternal and child nutrition in primary health care delivery services.
The All Progressives Congress (APC) controlled states have stated their resolve to align with the federal government on the declaration of 15 per cent annual allocation and release to healthcare services.
